case_name: Messrs. Sasa Musa Sugar Works Private Ltd. v. Workmen

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 746 and 747 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 746 and 747 of 1957.

facts.text: Appeals by special leave from judgments and orders dated June 3, 1955, and May 21, 1956, of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India, Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the judgments and orders dated June 3, 1955, and May 21, 1956, of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India, Calcutta,

facts.text: Award dated September 22, 1952, of the Industrial Tribunal, Bihar, published in the Bihar State Government Gazette on October 21, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: in Appeal No. Cal. 366/52 and Misc. Case No. 145 of 1955 respectively, arising out of an Award dated September 22, 1952, of the Industrial T

facts.text: Appellant is Messrs. Sasa Musa Sugar Works Private Ltd., a sugar factory in District Saran, Bihar.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, Messrs. Sasa Musa Sugar Works  Private  Ltd. is a sugar factory in District Saran  Bihar .

facts.text: The factory was established in 1932.

anchor.surface_text: The factory was established in 1932.

facts.text: In June 1942, a trade union was formed in this factory.

anchor.surface_text: In June 1942, a trade union was formed in this factory.

facts.text: In July 1943, trouble arose between the workmen and the management resulting in the discharge of three office-bearers of the union, including one Shams-ud-din, who was then the joint secretary.

anchor.surface_text: In July 1943, trouble arose between the workmen and the management resulting in the discharge of three office-bearers of the union, including one Shams-ud-din, who was then the joint secretary.

facts.text: Discharged workmen ordered to be reinstated in the beginning of 1944.

anchor.surface_text: That matter ,as referred to adjudication and the discharged workmen were ordered to be reinstated in the beginning of 1944.

facts.text: In December 1944, a large number of workmen were dismissed, including Shams-ud-din, who had become the president of the union.

anchor.surface_text: In December 1944, there was trouble again and a large number of workmen were dismissed, including Shams-ud-din, who had by number become the president of the union.

facts.text: Dismissed workmen ordered reinstated in August 1947.

anchor.surface_text: This dispute was again referred to an Industrial Tribunal, which again ordered reinstatement of the dismissed workmen in August 1947.

facts.text: In June 1951, the management discharged seventeen workmen, including Shams-ud-din, secretary of the union.

anchor.surface_text: But in June 1951, the management again discharged seventeen workmen, including Shams-ud-din, who was at that time secretary of the union.

facts.text: In December 1951, agreement arrived: twelve workmen reinstated, five including Shams-ud-din referred to adjudication.

anchor.surface_text: The trouble companytinued up to December 1951, when an agreement was arrived at between the union and the management, as a result of which twelve of the workmen were reinstated but five, including Shams-ud-din, were number and their cases were to be referred to adjudication.

facts.text: Reference pending since September 8, 1951, before Industrial Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: It appears, however, that another reference between the management and its workmen was already pending since September 8, 1951, before an Industrial Tribunal,

facts.text: On January 1, 1952, union issued notice to management listing 40 demands, threatening go-slow from January 9, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: But on January 1, 1952, a numberice was issued by the union to the management enlisting as many as 40 demands and it was threatened that if the demands were number met within seven days, the union would have to advise the work-men to adopt go-slow and call upon them to offer passive resistance with effect from January 9, 1952,

facts.text: Notice received by management on January 4, 1952; management contacted Labour Department and Sub-Divisional Magistrate at Gopalganj.

anchor.surface_text: This numberice was received by the management on January 4, which immediately companytacted the officers of the Labour Department as well as the Sub-Divisional Magistrate at Gopalganj.

facts.text: Go-slow began from January 9 to January 12, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The union, however, gave numberheed to this advice and go-slow began from January 9 and was companytinued till January 12, 1952.

facts.text: Labour Commissioner advised calling off go-slow on January 12, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Then the Labour Commissioner himself came to the factory on January 12 and advised Shams-ud-din who was the s moving spirit behind all this to call off the go-slow,

facts.text: Conciliation proceedings began January 17, 1952; agreement on some demands January 23, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Conciliation proceedings then began on January 17 and an agreement was arrived at as to some of the demands on January 23, and it was decided that further companyciliation proceedings would be held in February.

facts.text: Go-slow resorted to again from January 24 to January 31, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: But in spite of this agreement go-slow was again resorted to from January 24 to January 31.

facts.text: Management suspended thirty-three workmen by notice on night of January 31, 1952, as from February 1, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Consequently, the management suspended thirty-three workmen by a numberice given on the night of January 31 as from February 1.

facts.text: Management applied under s.33 on February 6, 1952, for permission to dismiss thirty-three workmen.

anchor.surface_text: As adjudication proceedings were pending since September 1951 between the management and its workmen, the former applied on February 6, 1952, under s. 33 of the Act for permission to dismiss the thirty-three workmen

facts.text: Management applied under s.33 on February 11, 1952, for permission to dismiss fifteen more workmen.

anchor.surface_text: and on February 11, 1952, for permission to dismiss the remaining fifteen workmen who had been suspended later.

facts.text: Workmen applied under s.33A on March 29, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The forty-eight workmen in their turn applied on March 29, 1952, under s. 33-A of the Act to the Industrial Tribunal

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal found no enquiry held by management before s.33 applications.

anchor.surface_text: On the first point, the Industrial Tribunal found that Do enquiry had been held by the management before the two applications, under s. 33 were made

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal held suspension not punishment but pending enquiry.

anchor.surface_text: On the second point, it held that the order of suspension was number as a measure of punisment in the circumstances of this case and that it was an order pending enquiry by the management

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal found deliberate unjustified go-slow by workmen in January and February 1952.

anchor.surface_text: On the third point, the Industrial Tribunal, after an elaborate discussion of the evidence, came to the companyclusion that there was a deliberate go-slow resorted to by the workmen in January and February 1952 and that it was unjustified

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal refused permission to dismiss 16 workmen for lack of evidence.

anchor.surface_text: It held that there was numberevidence to show that of the forty-eight workmen companycerned, sixteen workmen named by it had taken part in the go-slow or instigated it. It therefore refused the application under s. 33 with respect to these sixteen workmen.

facts.text: Supreme Court delivered judgment on April 29, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: 1959. April 29. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by WANCHOO, J.

facts.text: Supreme Court held suspension was not punishment but interim measure.

anchor.surface_text: We cannot agree with the Appellate Tribunal that the suspension in this case was substantive punishment and was number an interim order pending enquiry and proceedings before the Industrial Tribunal under s. 33.

facts.text: Supreme Court found evidence against all 48 workmen, including the 16.

anchor.surface_text: The finding, therefore, of the Industrial Tribunal that there was numberevidence against the sixteen workmen is patently perverse, for there was the same evidence against them as against the remaining thirty-two.
Appeals by special leave from the judgments and orders dated June 3, 1955, and May 21, 1956, of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India, Calcutta,

under s. 33 of the Industrial Disputes Act  hereinafter called the Act . The facts of the case are briefly these The appellant, Messrs. Sasa Musa Sugar Works  Private  Ltd. is a sugar factory in District Saran  Bihar .

concepts.interpretation: Requires prior permission from Industrial Tribunal to dismiss workmen during pendency of adjudication proceedings; Tribunal must grant permission if misconduct proved, cannot substitute lesser punishment.

issues.text: Whether the management's applications under s. 33 were liable to be rejected because they had not been preceded by any enquiry into the misconduct of the workmen

anchor.surface_text: The managements applications under s. 33 had number been preceded by any enquiry into the misconduct of the workmen and were, therefore, liable to be rejected

issues.text: Whether the order of suspension amounted to punishment and therefore contravened s. 33

anchor.surface_text: The order of suspension in this case amounted to punishment and therefore s. 33 had been contraven- ed

anchor.surface_text: There was an unjustified go-slow by the workmen in January and February 1952. On the first point, the Industrial Tribunal found that Do enquiry had been held by the management

holdings.text: The suspension in this case was not a punishment but was an interim measure pending enquiry and proceedings before the tribunal.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Suspension notices stated 'until further orders'; followed promptly by s.33 applications; confirmed by Industrial Tribunal finding upheld after workmen withdrew appeal.

holdings.text: It was not open to the Industrial Tribunal when it was asked to give permission to dismiss to substitute some other kind of punishment and give permission for that.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal's role under s.33 is binary: grant or refuse permission to dismiss if misconduct proved; cannot decide quantum of punishment.

holdings.text: Go-slow is serious misconduct which is insidious in its nature and cannot be countenanced.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirms Industrial Tribunal's finding of deliberate unjustified go-slow during conciliation; warrants dismissal.

holdings.text: The finding of the Industrial Tribunal that there was no evidence against the sixteen workmen is patently perverse.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Same evidence from same witnesses applied to all 48 workmen; no basis to distinguish 16.

holdings.text: On the findings of the Industrial Tribunal on the three points which have not been upset, the only order possible was to permit the management to dismiss the forty-eight workmen.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Misconduct proved against all; permission must be granted under s.33; Appellate Tribunal erred on punishment and perversity.

holdings.text: As the management held no enquiry after suspending the workmen, it is bound to pay the wages till a case for dismissal was made out in the proceedings under s.33.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No prejudice as full evidence before tribunal, but per precedent (Ranipur Colliery), pay wages absent domestic enquiry.

holdings.text: The applications under s.33 were not mala fide as suspension was not punishment.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects mala fides argument as predicated on suspension being punishment; applications filed promptly after suspension.

precedents.citation: Management of Ranipur Colliery v. Bhuban Singh 1

anchor.surface_text: Management of Ranipur Col- liery v. Bhuban Singh  1

precedents.case_name: Management of Ranipur Colliery v. Bhuban Singh
precedents.cited_proposition: management is bound to pay wages to workmen till a case for dismissal is made out in proceedings under s. 33 when no prior domestic enquiry is held and s. 33 proceedings substitute for it

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that on the findings of the Industrial Tribunal on the three points formulated by it which have number been upset by the Appellate Tribunal, the only order possible on the applications of the management under s. 33 was to permit it to dismiss the forty -eight workmen, provided there was evidence against them all. It was number open to the Industrial Tribunal when it was asked to give permission to dismiss to substitute some other kind of punishment and give permission for that. The Industrial Tribunal was satisfied that there was misconduct and that finding has been upheld by the Appellate Tribunal. As such if there was evidence that these forty-eight workmen were guilty of misconduct, the Industrial Tribunal was bound to accord permission asked for. We cannot agree with the Appellate Tribunal that the suspension in this case was substantive punishment and was number an interim order pending enquiry and proceedings before the Industrial Tribunal under s. 33.

outcome.relief_summary: Permission granted to management to dismiss all 48 workmen for serious misconduct of go-slow; suspension held interim, not punishment.
directions: Management bound to pay wages of workmen till case for dismissal made out in s.33 proceedings

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that on the findings of the Industrial Tribunal on the three points formulated by it which have number been upset by the Appellate Tribunal, the only order possible on the applications of the management under s. 33 was to permit it to dismiss the forty -eight workmen, provided there was evidence against them all. It was number open to the Industrial Tribunal when it was asked to give permission to dismiss to substitute some other kind of punishment and give permission for that. The Industrial Tribunal was satisfied that there was misconduct and that finding has been upheld by the Appellate Tribunal. As such if there was evidence that these forty-eight workmen were guilty of misconduct, the Industrial Tribunal was bound to accord permission asked for. We cannot agree with the Appellate Tribunal that the suspension in this case was substantive punishment and was number an interim order pending enquiry and proceedings before the Industrial Tribunal under s. 33.

edges.explanation: Holding Tribunal cannot substitute punishment addresses issue of Tribunal substituting judgment on quantum
Inferred from holding.resolves_issue field
